datafield.subfield: Edward Jablonski (1922-2004) was an author and biographer of American songwriters Harold Arlen, Irving Berlin, George Gershwin, and Alan Jay Lerner. The collection includes drafts, project files, articles, liner notes, research materials, business papers and correspondence related to his literary projects.

Harold Arlen : rhythm, rainbows, and blues.

did.head: Collection Summary
did.abstract: Edward Jablonski (1922-2004) was an author and biographer of American songwriters Harold Arlen, Irving Berlin, George Gershwin, and Alan Jay Lerner. The collection includes drafts, project files, articles, liner notes, research materials, business papers and correspondence related to his literary projects.

note.p: The following terms have been used to index the description of this collection in the Library's online catalog. They are grouped by name of person or organization, by subject or location, and by occupation and listed alphabetically therein.

processinfo.head: Processing History
processinfo.p: The Edward Jablonski Papers were processed and the finding aid coded for EAD format by Janet McKinney in 2012.

separatedmaterial.head: Transfers
separatedmaterial.p: Audiovisual materials have been transferred to the Library of Congress Motion Picture, Broadcasting, and Recorded Sound Division. An inventory of this material is available in the Music Division's collection file.

separatedmaterial.head: Other Repositories
separatedmaterial.p: Materials specifically related to The Gershwin Years are found in the Edward Jablonski and Lawrence D. Stewart Collection at the Harry Ransom Humanities Research Center, University of Texas at Austin.

userestrict.head: Copyright Status
userestrict.p: Materials from the Edward Jablonski Papers are governed by the Copyright Law of the United States (Title 17, U.S.C.) and other applicable international copyright laws.

accessrestrict.head: Access and Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: The Edward Jablonski Papers are open to research. Researchers are advised to contact the Music Division prior to visiting in order to determine whether the desired materials will be available at that time.
Certain restrictions to use or copying of materials may apply.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Researchers wishing to cite this collection should include the following information: [item, date, container number], Edward Jablonski Papers, Music Division, Library of Congress, Washington, D.C.

chronitem.event: Served with the U.S. Army Field Artillery Corp.
Founding member of Walden Records with Peter Bartok
Graduated from the New School for Social Research, New York, N.Y.
Published with Lawrence D. Stewart The Gershwin Years. Garden City, N.Y.: Doubleday
Published Harold Arlen: Happy With the Blues. Garden City, N.Y.: Doubleday
Published George Gershwin. New York: Putnam
Focused research on aviation history and published over 10 books on the subject
Published Encyclopedia of American Music. Garden City, N.Y.: Doubleday
Received the ASCAP Deems Taylor Award for Gershwin
Published Gershwin Remembered. Portland, Or.: Amadeus Press

eventgrp.event: Published Alan Jay Lerner: A Biography. New York: H. Holt
Published Harold Arlen: Rhythm, Rainbows, and Blues. Boston: Northeastern University Press

chronitem.event: Published Irving Berlin: American Troubadour. New York: Henry Holt
Died of heart failure in Manhattan

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Edward Jablonski Papers span the period of 1942-2003, with the majority of the materials dating from 1950-2000. The collection includes book project materials, articles, liner notes, drafts, and related correspondence and business papers. All research, correspondence, and business papers pertaining to a given project are filed with its draft materials.

The Project Files series chiefly consists of materials used in the preparation and publication of Jablonski’s books on such American composers and songwriters as Harold Arlen, Irving Berlin, and George Gershwin. Drafts, notes by chapter, research materials, and correspondence are present for each biographical work. These works include Harold Arlen: Happy With the Blues, Harold Arlen: Rhythm, Rainbows, and Blues, Gershwin Remembered and most extensively, Gershwin. Articles, liner notes, and other miscellaneous project material for each composer are then filed chronologically by date.

Other major compositional projects follow in alphabetical order, including The Encyclopedia of American Music, and the Music Lover's Encyclopedia. Materials for miscellaneous articles, liner notes, and other writings focusing on a particular composer or a general broader topic such as American musical theater, can be found filed chronologically by date.

Jablonski was also an author of aviation history, and there are several articles and correspondence related to his work in this field. These are compiled together with his other writings on various non-music related subjects.

Correspondence in the Miscellany series consists of personal letters and business papers, arranged either by last name of correspondent or by date. Notable individuals represented include Abe Berman, Peter Clay, Alan Dashiell, and David Cunard. The series also contains a small amount of miscellaneous personal items.

arrangement.head: Organization of the Edward Jablonski Papers
arrangement.p: The Edward Jablonski Papers are organized in two series:

did.unittitle: Materials for Harold Arlen: happy with the blues
Materials for Harold Arlen: rhythm, rainbows, and blues
Articles, program notes, and liner notes
Materials for Turkish folk music from Asia Minor
Materials for Irving Berlin: American troubadour
